questions.question_id: Are autorouter FPL accepted? Whether yes or no, are there recommended local alternatives?
questions.question_raw: Are autorouter FPL accepted? Whether yes or no, are there recommended local alternatives?
questions.question_text: Are autorouter FPL accepted? Whether yes or no, are there recommended local alternatives?

BE.answer_html: Yes. Local alternative (https://ops.skeyes.be ) not recommended

FR.answer_html: yes

DE.answer_html: FPL submitted via Autorouter or Foreflight work well for VFR as well as IFR

LU.answer_html: Yes. No particular local alternative. The Belgium ANSP provides an internet interface that can be used.

NL.answer_html: Yes, IFR only via EuroControl

SE.answer_html: Yes. Local alternative is aro.lfv.se.

GG.answer_html: Yes. Foreflight, SkyDemon, and Rocketroute are also in use by pilots based here.

JE.answer_html: yes - [input from others please on alternatives]

HU.answer_html: IFR: autorouter (and any other IFPS‑connected tool) works perfectly for flights involving Hungarian controlled airspace. VFR: autorouter support is limited; some cross‑border VFR plans will work, but for purely domestic VFR the recommended method is NetBriefing or contacting the ARO directly. There is no Hungarian ban on autorouter; it is simply another IFPS front‑end.

IE.answer_html: Yes. Autorouter accepted; IFPS/ARO also options. Flight plan can be filed or closed by telephone (+35361703750), Skydemon, Rocketroute, Foreflight etc.. Yes.  Presume the IAA FPL portal is recommended but I have never used it. Auto router or Foreflight routings are generally validated / accepted.

IT.answer_html: I use >Foreflight, have no experience with AR

MT.answer_html: Yes. This user uses Garmin Pilot for filing IFR FPL, and https://maltats.com to file  VFR FPL. If using MATS website to file, it is recommended to contract the MATS FPL office to confirm FPL accepted, tel: +356 2235 5543 (warning: the email receipt is auto-generated and does not confirm acceptance).

NO.answer_html: Yes, the accept third party options, but Avinor prefers that we use their own system witch you will find on IPPC.no

PL.answer_html: FPL web application available

questions.question_id: Are military airfields generally available for civilian use?
questions.question_raw: Are military airfields generally available for civilian use?
questions.question_text: Are military airfields generally available for civilian use?

BE.answer_html: No. A concession has been given to civil clubs by the Belgian Air Force to use following military aerodromes and sites outside military operations: EBBX, EBCV, EBDT, EBFN, EBFS, EBLE, EBUL and EBWE

FR.answer_html: no

DE.answer_html: Some yes but it is necessary to check the AIP and call them before. Some airfields are jointly used by military an civilian A/C, e.g. Rostock

LU.answer_html: n/a no dedicated military airfield

NL.answer_html: No, only for glider activities when not active

SE.answer_html: No, unless designated for joint use.

JE.answer_html: n/a - none in Channel Islands Control Zone

HU.answer_html: Not really. Some flight schools have contract with them to practice instrument approaches.

IE.answer_html:
Ireland has only one active military air base: Casement Aerodrome (Baldonnel, EIME).

It is a military-only aerodrome.

Strictly no civil access without formal Defence Forces approval.

Approvals are rare and typically limited to:
Government flights
State aircraft
International delegations
Emergency diversions where safety dictates
Occasional high-level diplomatic or humanitarian movements

Normal GA and commercial aircraft cannot request access.

NO.answer_html: No.

PL.answer_html: no, since Putin invaded Ukraine

questions.question_id: Are these rules generally abided by (or do lesser services try to "overcontrol")?
questions.question_raw: Are these rules generally abided by (or do lesser services try to "overcontrol")?
questions.question_text: Are the permission requirement generally abided by (or do lesser services try to "overcontrol")?

BE.answer_html: Generally abided by

FR.answer_html: usualy abided

DE.answer_html:
In the current early process of allowing VFR flying to unmanned airfields this gets more standardized now. The former "wanna-be-controllers"
are legally more restricted now.

NL.answer_html: Generaly abided to

SE.answer_html: Generally, yes. Occasionally AFIS phrases advice as if it were instructions.

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: AFIS and Radio units sometimes ‘over‑control’ in tone, using language that sounds like clearances. However, most Hungarian pilots understand the legal distinction and treat AFIS/Radio instructions as strong advice rather than binding ATC clearances when outside controlled airspace.

IE.answer_html:
AFIS in Ireland typically:

Provide traffic and runway information

Give wind, QNH, runway in use

Offer advisories, not clearances

Phrase instructions correctly (e.g., “Report final”, not “Cleared to land”). The dogmatism of the controller is often inversely correlated with his/her workload ….. Yes, typically Information / Radio is unattended.

NO.answer_html: Lesser services try to overcontrol sometimes (afis units).

questions.question_id: Are there any preferred weather services which particularly report local conditions?
questions.question_raw: Are there any preferred weather services which particularly report local conditions?
questions.question_text: Are there any preferred weather services which particularly report local conditions?

BE.answer_html: No.

FR.answer_html: https://aviation.meteo.fr, windy

DE.answer_html: Deutscher Wetterdienst (DWD) is the official and reliable source, but a lot of other weather forecast providers are available

LU.answer_html: Not really; MET service answers the phone but generally repeats the TAF/METAR in plain language on the phone when asked about local conditions. They are helpful beyond local conditions, though, and will help/discuss/analyse weather for whole route.

SE.answer_html: Yes. aro.lfv.se or northavimet.com

CH.answer_html: meteosuisse app with aviation weather addon, foreflight, GAFOR route particualarly useful

JE.answer_html: https://www.gov.je/weather/aviation

HU.answer_html: HungaroMet Hungarian Meteorological Service, website  https://aviation.met.hu/index2.php?lng=en Usefull website which is hungarian but with a lot of webcam possibilty: https://www.idokep.hu/webkamera

IE.answer_html: Various apps.  Local weather service (Met Eireann) seemingly has a lot of high-resolution aviation weather data that it does not publish, on the ground that published weather for aviation must meet stringent certification standards which have not been verified for this data.  CYA approach.  So we are left to rely on Windy, UK Met Office, Pilot Weather, Orbifly, etc etc. Official site is MetBriefing.ie and provides METAR, TAF, LLSigWx and Winds aloft.

MT.answer_html: Local weather forcast service is available over the phone 24/7, 365 days and you can speak with a human being. Local met office can advise re local conditions and volcanic ash / ASHTAM status (Etna). +356 2369 6687

NO.answer_html: Norwegian met office have a app called YR witch is often used, pilots also use a app from the Norwegian helicopter rescues that have met info and web cams (HemsWX).

PL.answer_html: https://awiacja.imgw.pl/

questions.question_id: Are there any specific requirements in the initial call for FIS?
questions.question_raw: Are there any specific requirements in the initial call for FIS?
questions.question_text: Are there any specific requirements in the initial call for FIS?

BE.answer_html: Squawk 2000

FR.answer_html: Typically say your registration number, then "CenterName (Paris/Lille…) N12345 Bonjour". They will reply "Bonjour N12345" and then you can give your details and request (can be in english or french)

DE.answer_html:
First just initical call: "Langen Information", own callsign and "Hallo", after their response: type of A/C, PoB, Origin, Destination, Position,
Altitude/FL, "Request Flight Information Service"

LU.answer_html: No, as standard: their callsign, your callsign, position, intentions

NL.answer_html: Calling Dutch Mill say position in initial call

SE.answer_html: If you have not filed a flight plan you are expected to provide details on position, level, route, aircraft type and POB.

GB.answer_html: center name, station name, request (service or transit). They wil lreply pass your message and you can then give your details

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: No. Maybe your callsign and squawk and alway add request traffic information. Example Budapest information, G-ABCD 5500 feet QNH 1021 over STEIN squawk 7012 inbound LHBS, request traffic information on route.

IE.answer_html: Position report and intentions consistent with ICAO Doc 4444 and the Irish AIP (ENR 1.1 & ENR 1.6). Flight plan not required.

IT.answer_html: registration, position, POB, fuel, next point and ETA next point

MT.answer_html: Callsign, type position , level, VMC/IMC, ETA entry point. See AIP ENR 2.1

NO.answer_html: No

PL.answer_html: no

questions.question_id: Are there Listening Squawks and if so, how do they work?
questions.question_raw: Are there Listening Squawks and if so, how do they work?
questions.question_text: Are there Listening Squawks and if so, how do they work?

BE.answer_html: 5101: listening to 126,90 (FIS)

FR.answer_html: no

DE.answer_html:
Yes within Transponder Mandatory Zones (TMZ). Squawk-code and listening frequency can be found in the map! No radio contact if ATC
does not contact the pilot from there side.

LU.answer_html: Not in the country per se, but in German airspace delegated to Luxembourg Radar

NL.answer_html: Amsterdam TMA 7020, Rotterdam TMA 7010 Is listen only but recommended to give a call and say intentions

SE.answer_html: No.

GB.answer_html: yes, squawk the frequency using mode C or S, Map is found in section 6.80 of latest AIP found here https://nats-uk.ead-it.com/cms-nats/opencms/en/Publications/AIP/

JE.answer_html: no

HU.answer_html: VFR fixed wing 7000 and rotary for 7001 but if someone doesn't file FPL very common to talk with FIC.

IE.answer_html: Yes. Usually used if nearby but not entering controlled airspace. (Dublin CTA/CTR 0440 freq 118.500, Shannon CTA/CTR 2677 freq 121.400, Cork CTA/CTR 2641 freq 119.900). There are listening squawks for Dublin and Shannon flight info areas but I suspect they are little used by anyone.

MT.answer_html: No

NO.answer_html: No, we only use 7000 for VFR but don't have listening squawks like in England.

questions.question_id: Can FIS grant clearance through Class D, C and B airspace?
questions.question_raw: Can FIS grant clearance through Class D, C and B airspace?
questions.question_text: Can FIS grant clearance through Class D, C and B airspace?

BE.answer_html: Happens rarely, they will rather hand you over to the airspace controller

FR.answer_html: depends, sometime yes, sometime they will direct you to contact the relevant unit on the radio

DE.answer_html:
FIS cannot grant a clearance on itsown but can relay a clearance from the resposible ATC-unit, but usually they hand-over to the responsible
ATC-unit before entering

LU.answer_html: Yes except ELLX CTR; FIS is the same human as ATC of all other airspace, so obviously it can.

NL.answer_html: Only for military CTR's when the CTR is not active by the military

SE.answer_html: There is no separate FIS in Sweden. (Except AFIS.) FIS is provided by ATC units.

GB.answer_html: no FIS, only the controlling station can provide clearance

JE.answer_html: no

HU.answer_html: FIS will coordinate with ATC and relay the clearence and FIC will hand over to the appropriate ATC.

IE.answer_html: Occasionally they will issue a delegated clearance from the controlling authority but usually you are passed on to the relevant ATS unit. Dublin, Shannon "FIS" is really ATC under a different label, and acts as FIS OCAS.  CAS clearance requires ATC. Yes they sometimes coordinate if passing through the zone, sometimes they transfer you to the tower/approach controller.

MT.answer_html: There is no FIS in Malta however the radar controller acts like a FIS when outside controlled airspace

NO.answer_html: No, they send you over to the correct handler but you have a personal responsibility to change before busting any C airspace.

PL.answer_html: from formal point of view you need FPL, but ATC usually can grant clearance through Class C or D

questions.question_id: Can you rely on FIS to advise you regarding approaching and penetrating such airspace?
questions.question_raw: Can you rely on FIS to advise you regarding approaching and penetrating such airspace?
questions.question_text: Can you rely on FIS to advise you regarding approaching and penetrating such airspace?

BE.answer_html: No

FR.answer_html: usually if workload permits. You can also ask for active zone ahead

DE.answer_html: FIS has radar facilities covering the entire country and warn you in most cases, but the PIC is finally responsible and can not fully rely on FIS

LU.answer_html: generally yes, but since some are right at the border or really close, they may not have enough time for that, you may have penetrated before finishing your initial call

NL.answer_html: In general yes when they are not too busy, so do not count on it

SE.answer_html: No.

GG.answer_html: (ATC, not FIS), and yes if you're IFR, no if you're VFR

JE.answer_html: n/a - only restricted area is in Class D

HU.answer_html: Yes absolutely. I think the Hungarian FIC is very prepared and helpful. They are fully equiped with radar and they are in the same ops room as the ACC and Budapest APP.

IE.answer_html: Legally PIC is responsible, but in practice FIS service is very good and will advise where workload allows.  Workload is not used as an excuse and FIS is very helpful.

IT.answer_html: no, in mountain areas no coverage 70% of time and misscomunications

MT.answer_html: Yes, they have you on radar. No

NO.answer_html: Usually, but you have the final responsibility to stay clear of those areas.

PL.answer_html: yes, they will help with local frequency

questions.question_id: Do any specific requirements or procedures apply when arriving on an instrument approach to an unmanned airfield?
questions.question_raw: Do any specific requirements or procedures apply when arriving on an instrument approach to an unmanned airfield?
questions.question_text: Do any specific requirements or procedures apply when arriving on an instrument approach to an unmanned airfield?

BE.answer_html: Not applicable as this is not allowed

FR.answer_html: If the circuit is active you need to overfly the field and not do a straight in approach.

DE.answer_html: Not applicable in Germany so far.

LU.answer_html: n/a the only airfield with instrument approaches is ELLX and ATC is staffed 24/7 (even though use of the airfield is banned 23:00LT-06:00LT, ATC is there for SAR flights etc)

NL.answer_html: NA in NL

SE.answer_html: Only if so prescribed by local rules.

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: According the local situations and procedures this is not possible now. If somebody does this the pilot must call Budapest ATS center to close the flight plan to avoid SAR alerted.

IE.answer_html: Coordinate with ATC; self-announce if AFIS/AG; maintain separation. Generally no instrument approaches to unmanned airfields. No ATC = no instrument appchs. All on an informal basis.  FIS will advise traffic and terrain is the responsibility of the PIC in Class G.

IT.answer_html: no such experience in Italy up to now.

MT.answer_html: n/a per above

NO.answer_html: From what I have found out, the answer is no.

questions.question_id: Flying under VFR in Class C airspace, what are the transponder requirements?
questions.question_raw: Flying under VFR in Class C airspace, what are the transponder requirements?
questions.question_text: Flying under VFR in Class C airspace, what are the transponder requirements?

BE.answer_html: mode S required

FR.answer_html: yes

DE.answer_html: transponder Mode S required (code 7000 if not otherwise instructed by ATC)

LU.answer_html: Mode S mandatory

SE.answer_html: Mode A+C (Mode C not required in control zones.)

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: Class C VFR: effectively mandatory – you should not expect to be able to operate in Class C without a transponder. All aircraft are expected to squawk Mode A/C or S as required, and ATC may require Mode C/S for access.

IE.answer_html: Required when operating IFR or entering a Transponder Mandatory Zone (charted and in the vicinity of Airports).  Most (all?) Class C overlaps with TMZs. Transponder reqd, Mode S, I don't know whether Mode C is still legal, probably not.

MT.answer_html: Per Class D above. Mode C

NO.answer_html: Required.

questions.question_id: Flying under VFR in Class D airspace, what are the transponder requirements?
questions.question_raw: Flying under VFR in Class D airspace, what are the transponder requirements?
questions.question_text: Flying under VFR in Class D airspace, what are the transponder requirements?

BE.answer_html: mode S required

FR.answer_html: yes

DE.answer_html: Class D (non-control zone) transponder Mode S required (code 7000 if not otherwise instructed by ATC)

LU.answer_html: Mode S mandatory

SE.answer_html: Mode A+C (Mode C not required in control zones.)

JE.answer_html: [I think Mode S - but unsure - the planes I fly comply!]

HU.answer_html: Class D VFR: effectively mandatory – you should not expect to be able to operate in Class D without a transponder. All aircraft are expected to squawk Mode A/C or S as required, and ATC may require Mode C/S for access.

IE.answer_html: N/a

MT.answer_html: All aircraft operating within controlled airspace in the Malta FIR/UIR, Malta CTA and Luqa TMA are required to operate with serviceable transponder having mode A4096 code and mode C altitude reporting capability.

NO.answer_html: Required.

questions.question_id: Flying under VFR in Class E airspace, what are the transponder requirements?
questions.question_raw: Flying under VFR in Class E airspace, what are the transponder requirements?
questions.question_text: Flying under VFR in Class E airspace, what are the transponder requirements?

FR.answer_html: no unless TMZ

DE.answer_html: not required but has to be switched on if equipped (code 7000)

LU.answer_html: n/a no class E

NL.answer_html: 7000 (Except for the mandatory listening squawk areas)

SE.answer_html: Mode A+C

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: We don't have class E

IE.answer_html: N/a

MT.answer_html: No Class E. Mode C

NO.answer_html: We don't use E much in Norway (a, c, d and g is most used), but I think transponder is required.

questions.question_id: Flying under VFR in Class G airspace, what are the transponder requirements?
questions.question_raw: Flying under VFR in Class G airspace, what are the transponder requirements?
questions.question_text: Flying under VFR in Class G airspace, what are the transponder requirements?

BE.answer_html: on if present

FR.answer_html: no

DE.answer_html: not required but has to be switched on if equipped (code 7000)

LU.answer_html: none

NL.answer_html: 7000 (Except for the mandatory listening squawk areas)

SE.answer_html: None.

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

IE.answer_html: Required when operating IFR or entering a Transponder Mandatory Zone (charted and in the vicinity of Airports).

MT.answer_html: Code 2000, when entering the Malta FIR/UIR from an adjacent region where the operation of transponders has not been required; and Code 7000, when not receiving an ATC service outside controlled airspace. Mode C

NO.answer_html: No requirement.

PL.answer_html: Transponder Mandatory Zones in G, Information  Service instructs for ident/squawk

questions.question_id: Flying under VFR in Class G and E airspace, are you required to use FIS?
questions.question_raw: Flying under VFR in Class G and E airspace, are you required to use FIS?
questions.question_text: Flying under VFR in Class G and E airspace, are you required to use FIS?

BE.answer_html: No

FR.answer_html: no

DE.answer_html: Not required but good airmenship!

LU.answer_html: No

NL.answer_html: Highly recommended

SE.answer_html: Not unless required for other reasons. For VFR in darkness according to SERA.

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: No.

IE.answer_html: Not required but is recommended and a good service is provided.

MT.answer_html: No. See AIP ENR 2.1

NO.answer_html: No

PL.answer_html: yes

questions.question_id: Flying under VFR, what are the requirements to enter Class D and Class C airspace?
questions.question_raw: Flying under VFR, what are the requirements to enter Class D and Class C airspace?
questions.question_text: Flying under VFR, what are the requirements to enter Class D and Class C airspace?

BE.answer_html: Clearance required

FR.answer_html: Class D, usually be in contact with ATC. Class C/TMA Be in contact with ATC and ask for transit. Reply will typically be "approved" with potential routing

DE.answer_html: Pilots need a specific clearance to enter provided by the responsible ATC-unit and need to stay in radio contact  during the transit

LU.answer_html: Obtain a clearance; phraseology is relaxed a bit like in France, being in contact and having given intentions, clearance is implied and ATC does not always say the word “cleared”

NL.answer_html: Clearance required

SE.answer_html: Clearance.

CH.answer_html: Radio communication for D, clearance for C (ex geneva tma)

GB.answer_html: You need an explicit clearance from the controlling station. Do not enter until you heard "Cleared to enter airspace"

JE.answer_html: ATC clearance required for zone entry and for VFR in the class D

HU.answer_html: To enter Class D or C under VFR you must establish two‑way radio contact with the appropriate ATC unit, operate an SSR transponder (Mode C/S) if equipped, and receive an explicit clearance to enter. You must then comply with all ATC instructions on headings, altitudes, routes and reporting points.

IE.answer_html: Only Class G and Class C in Ireland.  Clearance required to enter controlled airspace.

MT.answer_html: ATC clearance with specified altitude/level and routing. Make a request with the appropriate frequency

NO.answer_html: You need to call up ATC before entering and get a clearance.

PL.answer_html: need FPL to enter C or D

questions.question_id: For Airfield Information service-What permissions are required in the air?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required in the air?
questions.question_text: For Airfield Information service, what permissions are required in the air?

BE.answer_html: None – info only, operating at own discretion

FR.answer_html: Establish radio contact required, say your intention and position, and you'll get traffic and field information.

DE.answer_html: no permissions

NL.answer_html: Published VFR circuits are to be complied, report at least mid downwind and final

SE.answer_html: About 5 minutes before entering the flight information zone.

GB.answer_html: Establish radio contact required, say your intention and position, and you'll get traffic and field information.

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: FPL for in and out flight. Two way radio connection. Very interesting at important. If there is an IFR flight in the TIZ the AFISO can prohibit the other VFR traffic to hold until the IFR land or depart.

IE.answer_html:
Permission to enter controlled airspace (Class C/CTR/CTA/TMA) must be obtained from ATC before entry.

A specific CAS transit clearance is required if you intend to pass through controlled airspace.

IFR flight in controlled airspace requires an ATC IFR clearance before entering that airspace.

Special VFR (SVFR) inside a control zone requires an SVFR clearance from ATC when weather is below VFR minima.

When under ATC control, you must receive clearance for assigned altitudes, headings, or routings.

Permission is required from ATC for touch-and-go, stop-and-go, low approaches, or practice missed approaches. None - AFIS provides information only; pilots remain responsible for separation, circuit integration, and all air navigation decisions. None - Air/Ground Radio provides only basic traffic information; pilots are fully responsible for separation, circuit joining, and all air navigation decisions. CAS: FPL, zone entry N/a. Explicit clearance required to enter Class C airspace. None, just establish communications where available.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (tower or approach - Luqa Radar)

NO.answer_html: Information service.

questions.question_id: For Airfield Information service-What permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?
questions.question_text: For Airfield Information service, what permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?

BE.answer_html: None – info only, operating at own discretion

FR.answer_html: report position, intention. you'll get traffic and field information, not permission or clearance will be given. Pilot discretion

DE.answer_html: IFR clearance, Parking instructions

NL.answer_html: Own discretion. Exception EHSE call FIS before taxi

SE.answer_html: None.

CH.answer_html: report position, intention. you'll get traffic and field information, not permission or clearance will be given. Pilot discretion

GB.answer_html: report position, intention. you'll get traffic and field information, not permission or clearance will be given. Pilot discretion

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: Same as runway.

IE.answer_html: None - AFIS cannot issue taxi clearances; pilots announce intentions, follow published procedures, and maintain their own separation from traffic and vehicles. None - A/G cannot issue taxi clearances; pilots state intentions, follow local procedures, and maintain their own separation from aircraft, vehicles, and pedestrians. Taxi & parking instructions N/a. Clearance required. None, just establish communications where available.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (Luqa Ground)

NO.answer_html: Information service.

PL.answer_html: you can start engine without permissions from Airfield Information service; formally you don't need permissions from AIS at all but it's good idea to ask for rw in use, taxi instructions, line-up and departurte

questions.question_id: For Airfield Information service-What permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?
questions.question_text: For Airfield Information service, what permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?

BE.answer_html: None – info only, operating at own discretion

FR.answer_html: report position, intention. you'll get traffic and field information, not permission or clearance will be given. Pilot discretion

DE.answer_html: no permissions

NL.answer_html: Own discretion, report lining up

SE.answer_html: None.

CH.answer_html: report position, intention. you'll get traffic and field information, not permission or clearance will be given. Pilot discretion

GB.answer_html: report position, intention. you'll get traffic and field information, not permission or clearance will be given. Pilot discretion

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: no clearence, phraseology is "Runway free" Then the crew can depart and always the resposibilty is for the crew.

IE.answer_html:
At controlled aerodromes, you must obtain landing, takeoff, and go-around clearances from ATC.
At controlled aerodromes, ATC must clear you to enter, cross, or backtrack on any active runway. Startup clearance is generally required at most controlled aerodromes. None - AFIS does not issue clearances; pilots self-announce intentions and ensure the runway is safe before taking off, landing, backtracking, or crossing. None - A/G cannot issue take-off, landing, backtrack, or crossing clearances; pilots self-announce and ensure the runway is safe before use. Clearance to enter runway, takeoff/land N/a. Clearance required on all controlled surfaces.   Start up permission is typically required. None, just establish communications where available.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (Luqa Tower)

NO.answer_html: If runway is "Free" and report this to the pilot.

questions.question_id: For Airfield Radio service-What permissions are required in the air?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required in the air?
questions.question_text: For Airfield Radio service, what permissions are required in the air?

BE.answer_html: None – info only, operating at own discretion

FR.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

DE.answer_html: no permissions

SE.answer_html: About 5 minutes before entering the traffic circuit

CH.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

GB.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: All of the GA and sport airfield without TIZ airspace. Always check the airport manual and/or airport website. Sometimes it is the website of the aeroclub which is operating the field. Don't forget to check the https://ais.hungarocontrol.hu/vfrmanual. No any specific clearance will be issued. Somtimes the pilots talk to each other instead of a person on ground.

IE.answer_html:
Permission to enter controlled airspace (Class C/CTR/CTA/TMA) must be obtained from ATC before entry.

A specific CAS transit clearance is required if you intend to pass through controlled airspace.

IFR flight in controlled airspace requires an ATC IFR clearance before entering that airspace.

Special VFR (SVFR) inside a control zone requires an SVFR clearance from ATC when weather is below VFR minima.

When under ATC control, you must receive clearance for assigned altitudes, headings, or routings.

Permission is required from ATC for touch-and-go, stop-and-go, low approaches, or practice missed approaches. None - AFIS provides information only; pilots remain responsible for separation, circuit integration, and all air navigation decisions. None - Air/Ground Radio provides only basic traffic information; pilots are fully responsible for separation, circuit joining, and all air navigation decisions. CAS: FPL, zone entry N/a. Explicit clearance required to enter Class C airspace. None, just establish communications where available.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (tower or approach - Luqa Radar)

NO.answer_html: Information service.

PL.answer_html: entering traffic pattern, reporting position, clearance to land

questions.question_id: For Airfield Radio service-What permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?
questions.question_text: For Airfield Radio service, what permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?

BE.answer_html: None – info only, operating at own discretion

FR.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

DE.answer_html: Parking instructions

SE.answer_html: None.

CH.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

GB.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: All of the GA and sport airfield without TIZ airspace. Always check the airport manual and/or airport website. Sometimes it is the website of the aeroclub which is operating the field. Don't forget to check the https://ais.hungarocontrol.hu/vfrmanual. No any specific clearance will be issued. Somtimes the pilots talk to each other instead of a person on ground.

IE.answer_html: None - AFIS cannot issue taxi clearances; pilots announce intentions, follow published procedures, and maintain their own separation from traffic and vehicles. None - A/G cannot issue taxi clearances; pilots state intentions, follow local procedures, and maintain their own separation from aircraft, vehicles, and pedestrians. Taxi & parking instructions N/a. Clearance required. None, just establish communications where available.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (Luqa Ground)

NO.answer_html: Information service.

questions.question_id: For Airfield Radio service-What permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?
questions.question_text: For Airfield Radio service, what permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?

BE.answer_html: None – info only, operating at own discretion

FR.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

DE.answer_html: no permissions

SE.answer_html: None.

CH.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

GB.answer_html: Announce position and intention, coordinate with other planes

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: All of the GA and sport airfield without TIZ airspace. Always check the airport manual and/or airport website. Sometimes it is the website of the aeroclub which is operating the field. Don't forget to check the https://ais.hungarocontrol.hu/vfrmanual. No any specific clearance will be issued. Somtimes the pilots talk to each other instead of a person on ground.

IE.answer_html:
At controlled aerodromes, you must obtain landing, takeoff, and go-around clearances from ATC.
At controlled aerodromes, ATC must clear you to enter, cross, or backtrack on any active runway. Startup clearance is generally required at most controlled aerodromes. None - AFIS does not issue clearances; pilots self-announce intentions and ensure the runway is safe before taking off, landing, backtracking, or crossing. None - A/G cannot issue take-off, landing, backtrack, or crossing clearances; pilots self-announce and ensure the runway is safe before use. Clearance to enter runway, takeoff/land N/a. Clearance required on all controlled surfaces.   Start up permission is typically required. None, just establish communications where available.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (Luqa Tower)

NO.answer_html: Information service.

questions.question_id: For ATC at an airfield:-What permissions are required in the air?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required in the air?
questions.question_text: For ATC at an airfield, what permissions are required in the air?

BE.answer_html: Clearance required

FR.answer_html: Radio contact and follow instructions

DE.answer_html: Permission to enter the control zone, approach instructions and to clearance to land

LU.answer_html: clearance by TWR to enter the CTR

NL.answer_html: ATC on an airfield in NL always class C or D

SE.answer_html: Regular clearances. About 5 minutes before entering the control zone.

CH.answer_html: enter zone by radio contact, no explicit clearance for D

GG.answer_html: pretty much all: to enter airspace, special VFR, approach, hold, transit, land, touch'n'go…

JE.answer_html: clearance from ATC

HU.answer_html: Enter and cross CTR. Speciality that the cross is not allowed. It is allowed only for special reason such as aerial working, any SPO flight, SAR, medical or goverment flight.

IE.answer_html:
Permission to enter controlled airspace (Class C/CTR/CTA/TMA) must be obtained from ATC before entry.

A specific CAS transit clearance is required if you intend to pass through controlled airspace.

IFR flight in controlled airspace requires an ATC IFR clearance before entering that airspace.

Special VFR (SVFR) inside a control zone requires an SVFR clearance from ATC when weather is below VFR minima.

When under ATC control, you must receive clearance for assigned altitudes, headings, or routings.

Permission is required from ATC for touch-and-go, stop-and-go, low approaches, or practice missed approaches.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (tower or approach - Luqa Radar)

NO.answer_html: Clerance, height, landing, exiting/entering area.

questions.question_id: For ATC at an airfield:-What permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?
questions.question_text: For ATC at an airfield, what permissions are required on taxiways and aprons?

BE.answer_html: Clearance required

FR.answer_html: start for IFR, taxi clearance required and typical to ask permission to leave frequency before shutdown

DE.answer_html: Start-up clearance for IFR, taxi clearance, parking instructions, permission to leave frequency when arrived at the parking position

LU.answer_html: main taxiway B: clearance by TWR; aprons and minor taxiways are not controlled

NL.answer_html: Standard ATC clearances

SE.answer_html: Usually none, but some airports require permission from a ground or apron controller.

CH.answer_html: start for IFR, taxi for VFR

GB.answer_html: start for IFR and VFR, taxi clearance required

GG.answer_html: Startup and clearances (except on the Aeroclub's apron, where permission to startup is not required)

JE.answer_html: clearance from ATC

HU.answer_html: Taxi clearence, apron has own frequency but it is used for some special features the movement is handled by the ATC ground.

IE.answer_html: Clearance required.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (Luqa Ground)

NO.answer_html: Clerance to start up and to taxi the airplane.

PL.answer_html: required permitions for engine start, taxi, line-up and departure

questions.question_id: For ATC at an airfield:-What permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?
questions.question_raw: What permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?
questions.question_text: For ATC at an airfield, what permissions are required on the runway (ie take-off and land)?

BE.answer_html: Clearance required

FR.answer_html: Takeoff and landing clearance required

DE.answer_html: Clearance to take-off (IFR Clearance or VFR intructions to leave the control zone are normally provided before)

LU.answer_html: clearance by TWR

NL.answer_html: Standard ATC clearances

SE.answer_html: Regular clearances.

GG.answer_html: again all: to enter, to full-stop, to exit, to take off.

JE.answer_html: clearance from ATC

HU.answer_html: Landing, takeoff, backtrack, lineup, cross, taxi on  RWY.

IE.answer_html:
At controlled aerodromes, you must obtain landing, takeoff, and go-around clearances from ATC.
At controlled aerodromes, ATC must clear you to enter, cross, or backtrack on any active runway. Startup clearance is generally required at most controlled aerodromes.

MT.answer_html: Usual ATC clearances for operation at a controlled airport (Luqa Tower)

NO.answer_html: Clerance.

questions.question_id: How are FPL closed when arriving on a non-controlled airport?
questions.question_raw: How are FPL closed when arriving on a non-controlled airport?
questions.question_text: How are FPL closed when arriving on a non-controlled airport?

BE.answer_html: You have to call EBBR ARO (Briefing) : +32 2 206.25.40

FR.answer_html: either by calling phone number provided by ATC in the air (common) or +33 1 56 30 13 01

DE.answer_html: via telephone +49 6103 7075500

LU.answer_html: No experience; I would phone ELLX ARO

NL.answer_html: Local FIS will take care of it

SE.answer_html: At an AFIS airport, by AFIS. At airports without own ATS unit by radio to ATC or by phone to the ACC of the relevant FIR.

GB.answer_html: not required (no search and rescue will be triggered)

GG.answer_html: n/a all airports are controlled (EGJJ, EGJA, EGJB)

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: Two options. Before landig the pilot ask for the FPL closere with estimating the landing time, but mainly during training it is most adviseable to close the fliphtplan from the ground after landing on radio or to call the Flight information center FIC

IE.answer_html: (a) Radio to ATC anytime after exiting CAS, (b) OCAS when you're certain of being able to land, or (c) by telephone after landing. In the air with FIS prior to transfer to local airfield frequency or via phone on the ground (required within 30 minutes). Close via phone to Shannon ATC or via radio before landing or /online. Phone +35361703750

IT.answer_html: by phone to nearest ArO. Generic phone number is ARO PADOVA: +39 0679811011. NEED REPORT: REGISTRATION SIGN, TIME OF ARRIVAL, PLACE OF ARRIVAL.  Max 45 min after landing. Otherwise big problems :)

MT.answer_html: n/a, only one airport in Malta

NO.answer_html: By phone usually.

PL.answer_html: by phone, if yoiu don't close FPL, rersque procedures might start

questions.question_id: How far from destination would you generally first call a VFR airfield?
questions.question_raw: How far from destination would you generally first call a VFR airfield?
questions.question_text: How far from destination would you generally first call a VFR airfield?

BE.answer_html: 10NM/5 minutes out

FR.answer_html: 5 to 10 NM or 5 min

DE.answer_html: Normally 5 minutes before entering the circuit. It gives you enough time to create a picture of the the other traffic around by listening

LU.answer_html: no experience (unlikely a foreigner would visit them)

NL.answer_html: 10 minutes out

SE.answer_html: About 5 minutes.

CH.answer_html: downwind join, with overhead check of airfield if no afis. Base or straightin possible if communication/coordination with afis or tower

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have ATC

HU.answer_html: I woult say at least 5 minutes or 2 minutes from the airspace boudary. Example you are arriving to LHBS which is the bussiest GA airfield but without airspace. So at least 5 minutes. But if you arrive to LHPP it is enougn to call them 2 minutes before the  TIZ boundary.

IE.answer_html: Typically 5–10 nautical miles from the airfield if uncontrolled.

MT.answer_html: n/a. ATC clearance required to enter the TMA. 50nm

NO.answer_html: Usually when exiting the controlled airspace or in G airspace, about ten minutes out from the field. Depends witch airport it is and how much traffic they have.

PL.answer_html: in VFR radio reporting point, published in VFR AIP

questions.question_id: If arriving at a VFR airfield following an IFR flight, who is permitted to terminate IFR, and under what circumstance?
questions.question_raw: If arriving at a VFR airfield following an IFR flight, who is permitted to terminate IFR, and under what circumstance?
questions.question_text: If arriving at a VFR airfield following an IFR flight, who is permitted to terminate IFR, and under what circumstance?

BE.answer_html: You will be in radio contact with ATC or FIS and cancel IFR before calling the destination aerodrome

FR.answer_html: You can continue IFR until after landing. ATC or AFIS will closed your flight plan, if no ATC, you need to call to close it (it is common to receive the phone number in the air from ATC). It is important to close your flight plan, as not doing so will trigger search and rescue in France

DE.answer_html: A Y-FPL has to be filed with a defined waypoint for change from IFR to VFR. Only the pilot can cancel IFR at anytime if he is in VMC.

LU.answer_html: Unheard of for lack of VFR airfields that IFR-capable aircraft would use; the VFR airfields are basically dedicated parachuting / glider / acrobatics bases. Standard answer as per SERA is only the pilot.

NL.answer_html: PIC can terminate IFR in class G, E, D or C

SE.answer_html: Only the pilot can terminate IFR. That is needed only in controlled airspace when descending below the MVA.

GB.answer_html: Once leaving controlled airspace, it becomes pilot discretion

JE.answer_html: this is done by ATC - no pilot intervention required

HU.answer_html: Well as it is not possible to fly IFR under 4000 feet I think the answer is clear for this question.

IE.answer_html: PIC terminates IFR and closes flight plan in the air or via phone on the ground within 30 minutes.  Flight plan closure is mandatory. Airfield OCAS: Pilot terminates IFR when in VMC.  CAS:  I would expect IFR to VFR to be proposed or prompted by ATC. Pilot may cancel IFR with ATC when in VMC or safe visually.

IT.answer_html: pilot request IFR cancelation , ATC conferm it.

MT.answer_html: LMML is IFR/VFR. PIC may terminate IFR  at own discretion and join VFR circuit. Note that LMML is declared IFR at BKN15 . Only one airfield in Malta

NO.answer_html: The PIC, if VFR is not longer possible, If you want to switch from IFR to VFR during an approach etc., etc.…

PL.answer_html: FPL can be terminated via phonecall to ATC

questions.question_id: If IFR practical in Class G, is a clearance required?
questions.question_raw: If IFR practical in Class G, is a clearance required?
questions.question_text: If IFR practical in Class G, is a clearance required?

BE.answer_html: Yes

FR.answer_html: yes, you need to be in contact with ATC

NL.answer_html: Yes

SE.answer_html: No. (What would that even mean!?)

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: Within pure Class G no ATC clearance is required to fly under IFR – you are outside controlled airspace. However, when you intend to enter controlled airspace (CTR/TMA or upper airspace) you must obtain the normal IFR clearance from the appropriate ATC unit. So: no clearance needed for IFR in ‘pure’ G, but a clearance is always needed for any controlled segment.

IE.answer_html: No, but AIP ENR 1.3:  An IFR flight operating outside controlled airspace … shall maintain an air-ground voice communications watch on the appropriate communication channel and establish two-way communication

MT.answer_html: No , see above. Yes

NO.answer_html: Yes.

questions.question_id: If IFR practical in Class G, is an ATC service required?
questions.question_raw: If IFR practical in Class G, is an ATC service required?
questions.question_text: If IFR practical in Class G, is an ATC service required?

BE.answer_html: Contact with FIS is recommended

FR.answer_html: yes

NL.answer_html: Yes

SE.answer_html: No. A FIS service may be required depending on airspace and level. (Ref. AIP GEN 1.1 para 6.2.)

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: No, only flight information service will be provided in class G.

IE.answer_html:
No,  An IFR flight operating outside controlled airspace … shall maintain an air-ground voice communications watch on the appropriate communication channel and establish two-way communication. 
Dublin / Shannon FIS provide a service broadly similar to flight following. ATC service required for separation

MT.answer_html: Although flying in Class G airspace, ATC would still like to be informed of any changes unless you are a military asset and 'operational'. No , see above

NO.answer_html: Yes/no. In G airspace you may get a flight following, it's not required to have communication along the way. The rule is that you need to have the possibility to do so if required.

PL.answer_html: Information Service available in G. I heard on radio pilots requesting IS to open (filed) FPL

questions.question_id: If IFR practical in Class G, is an FPL required, if so, does that FPL have to filed before flight?
questions.question_raw: If IFR practical in Class G, is an FPL required, if so, does that FPL have to filed before flight?
questions.question_text: If IFR practical in Class G, is an FPL required, if so, does that FPL have to filed before flight?

BE.answer_html: FPL is required and should be filed before flight, FIS is generally too busy to accept inflight FPL.

FR.answer_html: FPL should be filed, if not IFR FPL, ATS can give you a clearance in the air

NL.answer_html: FPL is required to be filed before the flight

SE.answer_html: Depends on airspace and level. (Ref. AIP GEN 1.1 para 6.2.) Does not have to be filed before flight.

GG.answer_html: FPL is required, >1 hour before flight

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: IFR is mandatory for all flights in Hungarian FIR and it must be filed before the flight although if AFIL needed the FIC will accept it but with difficulty

IE.answer_html: Yes, I believe this would be a prerequisite of getting ATC service even if the whole flight was in Class G and in the FIR. Flight plan recommended but not mandatory. Flight plan will make AIS / FIS services easier to access.

MT.answer_html: Flights from outside FIR require FPL. An IFR flight could not depart without FPL as Malta is in  controlled airspace.  Thus practical application is limited. Yes. FPL is always required when flying IFR in Malta including local IFR training slots

NO.answer_html: Difficult to answer, but I think the answer is no. You just have to be able to communicate with ATC and have a functioning transponder.

PL.answer_html: FPL not required in G (VFR); I never flown IFR but FPL has checkbox to mark IFR/VFR

questions.question_id: If joining IFR from a VFR airfield what are the requirements in terms of clearances to start IFR?
questions.question_raw: If joining IFR from a VFR airfield what are the requirements in terms of clearances to start IFR?
questions.question_text: If joining IFR from a VFR airfield what are the requirements in terms of clearances to start IFR?

BE.answer_html: Request IFR pickup from FIS, they will hand you over to the next frequency that will give you initial clearance and squawk.

FR.answer_html: You can depart VFR and call ATC to get your clearance. If you can't depart VFR, you can get your clearance on the ground by calling relevant unit phone number listed in AIP or by local knowledge

DE.answer_html:
A Z-FPL has to be filed with a defined waypoint for change from VFR to IFR. ATC provides pilots with the clearance in the air and IFR
starts when the A/C is above the local Minimum Vectoring Altitude (MVA). Until then the A/C is still VFR and has legally to stay in VMC!

LU.answer_html: Unheard of for lack of VFR airfields that IFR-capable aircraft would use; the VFR airfields are basically dedicated parachuting / glider / acrobatics bases. If I had to do it, I’d call up Luxembourg Radar (the ATC in charge of the TMA / controlled airspace covering the whole country); by phone and/or after takeoff.

NL.answer_html: After start-up ask the local FIS to call ATC for a clearance

SE.answer_html: None. A clearance is required only before entering controlled airspace.

CH.answer_html: request start, get squawk and get frequency to call for the join

GB.answer_html: Depart VFR or IFR outside controlled airspace and call London Information for join on the radio. Some airport will list in the AIP phone number and procedure when uncontrolled

GG.answer_html: a FPL and clearance to enter airspace.

JE.answer_html: clearance is required to enter the Channel Islands Zone - ATC will provide VFR or IFR as requested by pilot

HU.answer_html: The same, you are not allowed to pick up any IFR until you reach controlled airspace or 4000 feet in uncontrolled airspace.

IE.answer_html:
Clearance required before entering controlled airspace; none needed in Class G. Airports such as Weston coordinate IFR clearances with Dublin but you depart VFR, on occasion you depart VFR and contact Dublin (or Shannon) before entering controlled airspace. Airfield OCAS: FPL activation, ATC clearance.  CAS:  Clearance given by ATC before departure. In Class G no clearance available / required, but a controlled airspace join is readily available on initial contact with FIS.
All arispace from FL upwards is Class C in Ireland, in addition to airspace around controlled airports.

IT.answer_html: outside of terminal area, on contact full report; registration, aircraft type, POB, fuel on board.

MT.answer_html: Normal procedures apply for Zulu FPL with IFR pickup as agreed with ATC in initial clearance. Advise ATC when and which point you would like to pick up your IFR

NO.answer_html: The PIC  has to contact ATC and inform them of the intention.

PL.answer_html: you can ask ATC controller to open your filed FPL

questions.question_id: If so, what permissions are needed?
questions.question_raw: If so, what permissions are needed?
questions.question_text: If military airfields are available, what permissions are needed?

DE.answer_html: In some places you need a PPR

SE.answer_html: If designated for joint use according to local rules. (Same as for any civilian airport.)

JE.answer_html: n/a - none in Channel Islands Control Zone

NO.answer_html: You need to contact them to get permission, either in air or before the flight starts.

questions.question_id: If so, is an FPL generally considered sufficient?
questions.question_raw: If so, is an FPL generally considered sufficient?
questions.question_text: If PPR is required, is an FPL generally considered sufficient?

BE.answer_html: No – phone call upfront is best approach

FR.answer_html: not applicable

DE.answer_html: A FPL is not sufficient if PPR is required.

LU.answer_html: no

NL.answer_html: Yes, if required

SE.answer_html: Emphatically no. (PPR means that you can be refused so you must be in contact with the AD.)

GG.answer_html: no, handling is mandatory (ASG, Aiglle or Aero club), and so is a GAR if you're coming from outside the bailiwick of Guernsey

JE.answer_html: [unsure for visiting aircraft]

HU.answer_html: Always check the airport website and the relevant AIP. But they will receive your FPL via AFTN but they won't contact you to clarify your intention.

IE.answer_html: No

IT.answer_html: no, need to be requested at handler

MT.answer_html: No, handlers need to apply for a parking slot and approval from the airport authoritues. No. The Transport Malta PPR number should be noted in FPL RMK18.

NO.answer_html: For Avinor airports, yes.

questions.question_id: Is a clearance required for a VFR flight in Class G or E airspace?
questions.question_raw: Is a clearance required for a VFR flight in Class G or E airspace?
questions.question_text: Is a clearance required for a VFR flight in Class G or E airspace?

BE.answer_html: No (no class E airspace in Belgium)

FR.answer_html: no

DE.answer_html: No

LU.answer_html: No. Being in contact with Luxembourg Radar (serving as FIS) is good practice.

NL.answer_html: No

SE.answer_html: No. (What would that even mean!?)

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: No. We use only the following classes. G for all of the non-controlled airspace and C for the controlled airspace except LHBP CTR which is class D

IE.answer_html: No. Ireland only has Class G (uncontrolled) and Class C (controlled) airspace. No Class E in Ireland.

MT.answer_html: No. There is no Class E in the Malta FIR. The island of Malta is inside Class D airspace below the Class C TMA. Yes

NO.answer_html: No, we use G in Norway and you don't need clearance to enter the airspace

PL.answer_html: in G: clearance NOT required; we don't have E in Poland

questions.question_id: Is a FPL required when crossing a FIR boundary?
questions.question_raw: Is a FPL required when crossing a FIR boundary?
questions.question_text: Is a FPL required when crossing a FIR boundary?

BE.answer_html: EBBU→LFFF and EBBU→EGTT

FR.answer_html: no

DE.answer_html: Not as long as the flight stays within the German boundaries

LU.answer_html: Not required by Belgium/Luxembourg (which form a single FIR); required by neighbouring France with 1h PN

NL.answer_html: FIR EHAA covers all of Netherlands

SE.answer_html: No.

JE.answer_html: yes

HU.answer_html: Yes.

IE.answer_html: Yes.

IT.answer_html: for my plane yes, for GA propeller not. (no type rating required )

MT.answer_html: Yes. When the departure and destination are both LMML however you are going to operate outside Maltese FIR, a FPL is required

NO.answer_html: Yes.

questions.question_id: Is a FPL required when crossing an international boundary from neighbouring countries?
questions.question_raw: Is a FPL required when crossing an international boundary from neighbouring countries?
questions.question_text: Is a FPL required when crossing an international boundary from neighbouring countries?

BE.answer_html: When crossing the border with France or UK, not required for Netherlands and Germany

FR.answer_html: yes

DE.answer_html: In general a VFR FPL is required if the flight crosses the German boundaries but there are exemptions, e.g. NL

LU.answer_html: Not required by Luxembourg; required by neighbouring France with 1h PN

NL.answer_html: Highly recommended for VFR flights into Belgium or Germany

SE.answer_html: Yes. Also when crossing a national boundary from international waters.

JE.answer_html: yes

HU.answer_html: Yes.

IE.answer_html: Yes.

MT.answer_html: Yes

NO.answer_html: Yes.

questions.question_id: Is an FPL required for a VFR flight?
questions.question_raw: Is an FPL required for a VFR flight?
questions.question_text: Is an FPL required for a VFR flight?

BE.answer_html: Mandatory when crossing the border with France or UK, expected when operating along the coastline

FR.answer_html: no

DE.answer_html: No written FPL required for a flight within the German boundaries

LU.answer_html: As per SERA; use of ELLX (controlled aerodrome) requires FPL (but national VFR can be abbreviated FPL on the phone); transit of TMA can be done with abbreviated AFIL

NL.answer_html: Flying to or from a controlled airport and night VFR

SE.answer_html: Not unless required for other reasons. For VFR in darkness according to SERA.

JE.answer_html: yes

HU.answer_html: For VFR flights only the following cases require FPL. 1. NVFR 2. VFR flight leave or arrive to TIZ airport. 3. When a glider wants to fly into clouds. 4. When any of the VFR filghts want to enter controlled airspace. 5. For international flights 6. When a flights wants to get SAR and traffic advisory on route.

IE.answer_html:
Only if entering controlled airspace or crossing the FIR boundary when day VFR.  
Night VFR requires a flight plan and continuous ATS communication when departing the circuit. Yes but only if entering CAS.  "Abbreviated FPLs" per SERA rules are not normally accepted.

IT.answer_html: no, but i fly Jet so no VFR at all (almost)

MT.answer_html: FPL only required if crossing FIR boundary. For local flights, ATC clearance is sufficient. For a local flight, No

NO.answer_html: No.

PL.answer_html: no

questions.question_id: Is IFR permitted and practical in Class G?
questions.question_raw: Is IFR permitted and practical in Class G?
questions.question_text: Is IFR permitted and practical in Class G?

BE.answer_html: Yes, provided that you are already IFR first in class C/D. ATC will warn you that you will get in uncontrolled airspace but if you accept it is allowed at own responsibility.

FR.answer_html: yes

DE.answer_html: Not permitted!

LU.answer_html: Not practical; permission is moot, as whole country is covered by ELLX TMA; vanishingly little, if any, class G low enough for legal IFR cruise.

NL.answer_html: Yes

SE.answer_html: Yes

CH.answer_html: no, only when on a instrument approach crossing class G

GG.answer_html: There is no class G (D and A only)

JE.answer_html: n/a - only Class A & D airspace

HU.answer_html: IFR flight only above 4000 feet in class G, and it is not common, but possible. All the airport with the airspace of class G are have instrument procedures so there is possible to depart and arrive under IFR.

IE.answer_html:
Yes
AIP ENR 1.4:  IFR and VFR flights are permitted and receive flight information service if requested. … ATC clearance is not required.
AIP END 1.3:  An IFR flight operating outside controlled airspace … shall maintain an appropraite cruising level

MT.answer_html: No prohibtion, but see below:. Yes

NO.answer_html: Yes.

PL.answer_html: yes

BE.answer_html: Complex airspace. See https://mobilit.belgium.be/sites/default/files/documents/publications/2022/Airspace%20Infringement%20Leaflet%20V2.pdf. One FIS controller expecting you to know AIP by heart, all others are friendly,

Quite a few airport have Visual Prescribed Track procedure after IFR approach, some airport have the approach broken down in two plates INA (contain IAF) and FNA (contains final approach) make sure you study both

LU.answer_html: ELLX traffic circuit has crazy / dangerous / sharp turn base-to-final; you are responsible for your safety; fly something safe rather than crashing trying to follow the line on the map

NL.answer_html: In general VFR crossing of the Schiphol CTR is not granted. When your IFR flight starts from an uncontrolled airfield make sure IFR pickup is in the EHAA FIR.  IFR entering or crossing of the Schiphol TMA below FL120 is not appreciated, can cause delays and re-routing.  IFR entering or crossing of the Schiphol TMA below FL120 is not appreciated, can cause delays and re-routing. Mode S required > 1200ft. 8.33 Khz com and 432Mhz ELT mandatory

SE.answer_html: Unless otherwise charted for a flight information zone, the transition altitude in class G is 5000 ft, or 3000 ft AGL if higher.

CH.answer_html: Subscribing to the Skyguide manual is recommended as it contains most relevant information, for example the VFR manual and airport information. EFB have option to purchase (for example foreflight) or subscribe to https://skybriefing.com

GB.answer_html: uncoordinated system of FIS/radar facility, you will need initiate new contact each time. Multiple class of service (Basic Service, Traffic Service, Deconfliction), zero tolerance for airspace infringement

GG.answer_html: We are very small, and not part of Europe or UK.  You'll generally only fly here if you're based, visiting or in transit between France/Spain and the UK.

GR.answer_html:
Only 9 airports with avgas
Handling can be very expensive

HU.answer_html:
Many regional airports have Class G TIZs with mandatory radio and often mandatory transponders, which feels unusual compared to some other states.
Budapest FIC is sectorised with multiple frequencies and provides very proactive support, including help with border crossings, active areas and even overdue‑flight checks.

IE.answer_html: No IFR clearance required in Class G.

IT.answer_html: Flying southbound: odds levels, flying north even levels.

MT.answer_html:
Pilots are advised to famliarise with the MALTA AIP at

questions.question_id: What are general rules, views and attitudes towards cloudbreak at an airport followed by VFR transit to an airfield?

BE.answer_html: This is an accepted practice

FR.answer_html: Possible, you need to maintain VFR

DE.answer_html:
This is generally accepted and practised if the VMC minima are given after the cloudbreak and the transit can be done above
minimum flight hight (500 resp. 1000 ft AGL)

LU.answer_html: No experience; I see no reason it would be problematic

NL.answer_html: Request will be granted civil airports only

SE.answer_html: Don't know.

GB.answer_html: common in class G and pilot discretion

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have instrument approaches

HU.answer_html: Well if you can fly below the clouds at 4000 feet the situation is ok, but if there is lower cloudbase the only possiblity to proceed and airfield wiht instrument approach and when you have clear and positve ground contact you can proceed to the VFR airfield. It is a very rare situaion. Not mentioning when some fly this procedure illegally and hoping not colliding with any ground object. (at least two major accindent happened in the last 10 year )

IE.answer_html: All on an informal basis.  FIS will advise traffic and terrain is the responsibility of the PIC in Class G. IFR, that seems ok (airport in CAS).  Otherwise avert your eyes.  OCAS there are no "airports".

MT.answer_html: n/a per above

NO.answer_html: I don't know, but I think this should be fine in most cases.

questions.question_id: What are the accepted norms for joining a visual circuit?
questions.question_raw: What are the accepted norms for joining a visual circuit?
questions.question_text: What are the accepted norms for joining a visual circuit?

BE.answer_html: Typically 1000’ AGL, reduced power for noise abatement

FR.answer_html: downwind join, with overhead check of airfield if no afis. Base or straightin possible if communication/coordination with afis or tower

DE.answer_html: Direct in on long final or entering direct base is accepted if traffic permits

LU.answer_html: ELLX maintain A020 as per VAC chart; call TWR at the mandatory reporting points and as instructed; other fields no experience (unlikely a foreigner would visit them)\

NL.answer_html: Non controlled airfields circuit altitude is usually 700 ft AAL. Check VFR plate for exeptions

SE.answer_html: Unless local procedures dictate otherwise, arrive over the airfield 500' above circuit altitude, descend into the traffic circuit, preferably on the dead side.

CH.answer_html: downwind join, with overhead check of airfield if no afis. Base or straightin possible if communication/coordination with afis or tower

GG.answer_html: Pattern direction and leg to be joined will be advised by ATC.

JE.answer_html: no really applicable

HU.answer_html: All of the worldwide form is ok, but from the old "eastern" style we use to join the so called 2nd point of pattern (crosswind+donwind intersercion) or the 3rd pont (donwind and baseleg intersection)

IE.answer_html:
Join overhead at 1,000 ft above circuit height
Cross runway midpoint
Descend on the dead side
Cross midfield at circuit height
Join downwind with established traffic.

MT.answer_html: ATC can clear you to any part of the circuit from short to wide base or long final. Per ATC clearance

NO.answer_html: Calling up on the radio, say intentions, follow the traffic pattern.

questions.question_id: What are the rules and general practices for approaching an airfield without IAPs in poor weather?
questions.question_raw: What are the rules and general practices for approaching an airfield without IAPs in poor weather?
questions.question_text: What are the rules and general practices for approaching an airfield without IAPs in poor weather?

BE.answer_html: Cancel IFR when in sight of terrain, follow published traffic circuits, VFR airfields will be closed in IMC so have an IFR alternate

FR.answer_html: You need to become VFR by either using another airfield approach or descend to MSA while in contact with ATC for class G

DE.answer_html: Approaching a VFR-only airfield is only permitted if the VMC minima are given

LU.answer_html: Don’t do it; note that ELNT has the village church bell tower on final in one direction.

NL.answer_html: NA in NL

SE.answer_html: No particular rules or practises.

GB.answer_html: if outside controlled airspace pilot discretion, if inside controlled airspace minimum will be listed

GG.answer_html: All airports have IAPs.  If they are not functioning, and weather is poor, don't land.  Fog is a significant and regular hazard here. Even commercial flights have to abandon landing on a regular basis.

JE.answer_html: n/a - all airfields have instrument approaches

HU.answer_html: There are no special Hungarian rules that would allow you to ignore normal VFR minima at an airfield without published approaches. If the destination has no instrument procedure you are expected to arrive in VMC with the applicable VFR visibility and cloud separation. Standard practice is to divert to an IFR airport. Tipical scenario when somone arriving to LHTL or to LHBS but the weather is under VMC the diversion to LHBP is the only possibilty mainly when the regional IFR airports are closed.

IE.answer_html: OCAS: Most pilots will avoid this situation.  The better-qualified pilot needs to be familiar with local obstacles and have a pre-planned protocol.  Garmin Visual Approaches very helpful but the unadjustable 3 deg GS is shallow so you need to know the obstacles situation.  Rules: see SERA; practices:  proceed at your own risk.  CAS:  I can't think of any examples of no-IAP airport in CAS here. All on an informal basis.  FIS will advise traffic and terrain is the responsibility of the PIC in Class G. No improvised IFR allowed; divert unless VMC achievable.

IT.answer_html: what you mean "without", not available? if so, no experience.

MT.answer_html: n/a as LMML is the only airfield and  has IFR procedures for all runways. LMML is a VFR/IFR Airport

NO.answer_html: You need to have access to updated charts.

BE.answer_html: Don’t when active. Activity known by FIS. FIS may warn you before entering but don’t count on them for this

FR.answer_html: N/A only R and P zone

DE.answer_html: Entering permitted with caution, only recommended if reliable information is recieved on potential activity

LU.answer_html: n/a there are none

NL.answer_html: By Notam, in doubt ask FIS

SE.answer_html: No permission needed. Good airmanship dictates that you check the status with ATS and avoid if necessary.

GB.answer_html: Do not enter, you may ask for transit but not always possible. Information about the areas can be found in the official AIP https://nats-uk.ead-it.com/cms-nats/opencms/en/Publications/AIP/ section 5 search for EGDnnn

JE.answer_html: n/a - none in Channel Islands Control Zone

HU.answer_html: Danger areas and military areas have operation time which is published in the Airspace use plan and in NOTAMS, so it is possible to prepare but if you contact with FIC they always will help you to avoid.

IE.answer_html:
Not prohibited, but entry is discouraged when the area is active.
Danger may include: Firing, Artillery,UAVs, High-energy military operations,Air-to-ground activity
ATC can advise “active” or “inactive” but cannot clear you into a danger area.
Normal Practice:  Check NOTAMs and AIP ENR 5.1.
Most Irish VFR pilots avoid active D-areas; crossing inactive ones is normal. Active by Notam q.v.  D5 in Wicklow is very often active, best avoided.  Some Ds are rarely active, it seems.

MT.answer_html: Danger Areas are in controlled airspace. ATC will tactically route aircraft clear. ATC instruct you not to enter danger areas in controlled airsapce

NO.answer_html: Usually this will not trigger a response og report.

PL.answer_html: no entry

IE.answer_html:
Published in the AIP (ENR 5.5).
Gliding sites may have winch launching to up to 3,000–4,000 ft AGL.

Normal Practice:
Overflying a glider site below 4,000 ft AGL is strongly discouraged.
GA traffic usually gives a broad berth laterally and avoids flying overhead. Look out, call on radio if concerned. FIS will notify is jump area active.

questions.question_id: What are the rules and normal practices regarding penetration of:-Military Areas
questions.question_raw: Military Areas

questions.question_prefix: What are the rules and normal practices regarding penetration of:

BE.answer_html: These will be Prohibited/Restricted/Danger Areas

FR.answer_html: See Restricted Area

DE.answer_html: Entering permitted if cleared by the responsible ATC-unit or the areas is decleared as not active

LU.answer_html: don’t (when active; read NOTAMs / ask FIS)

SE.answer_html: There are no specific military areas. The usual airspace structure (Controlled airspace, R-areas, TRAs etc.) are used to segregate military activity.

JE.answer_html: n/a - none in Channel Islands Control Zone

HU.answer_html: Military areas have operation time which is published in the Airspace use plan and in NOTAMS, so it is possible to prepare but if you contact with FIC they always will help you to avoid. There are TRAs where the military pilots are practicing. Their airspaces acitve only during weekdays. The FIC will inform you when it is active. The process is the following, if there is an airspace planned in the airspase use plan the airspace management cell AMC will inform all of the services at least 30 minutes before the TRA is active, than if the TRA is active all of the civil aircraft must leave it. If there isa special operation such as pipeline check aerial working or agricultural working, the military control can grant individual clearance for them.

IE.answer_html:
Rules:

Some are designated as restricted or danger areas. Non-designated low-flying areas do not prohibit GA entry.

Normal Practice:
GA pilots generally avoid known military low-flying corridors out of courtesy and safety.  ATC sometimes provides traffic advisories (e.g., “military fast jet activity reported”).
Military traffic does not have right-of-way-the rules of the air still apply. Areas south and west of Baldonnel are supposed to be avoided and are quite active, but penetration does not seem to have consequences.  Best to call Baldonnel ATC to advise of your presence. Clearance rquired to enter MOA 4,500 and above when active.  Coordinated via FIS.

MT.answer_html: Activated and controlled on a tactical basis.

NO.answer_html: A report will be created and the result is dictated by the severity of the incident.

PL.answer_html: no entry

BE.answer_html: Avoid overflying. Activity known by FIS. Skydiving planes will be in contact with ATC (Brussels Departure) – frequency can be monitored

FR.answer_html: ATC will notify you parachute activity and ask you to avoid

DE.answer_html: Ask FIS or on local Radio frequency about activity and enter with caution, avoid if no reliable information available

NL.answer_html: To be avoided, in doubt ask FIS

SE.answer_html: Avoided as dictated by airmanship.

CH.answer_html: ATC will notify you parachute activity and ask you to avoid

IE.answer_html:
Published in the AIP; typically designated as DZ or within Danger Areas.

When active:
Do not overfly, Keep clear vertically and laterally, Avoid the upwind side where aircraft climb and drop

Normal Practice:
Parachute aircraft broadcast on the local frequency before drops.
Pilots stay well clear (2–3 NM horizontally, 2,000–3,000 ft vertically).
At busy locations (e.g., Clonbullogue), overhead joins are avoided on active days. Charts mark erratic and inconsistent areas, penetrate at your own risk.  The most common one EICL I would check on radio for status. FIS will notify is jump area active.

NO.answer_html: Usually this will not trigger a response og report.

On an IFR flight with ATC coordination, or
A VFR flight where the controlling authority has confirmed inactive status.

Entry into or exit from Germany from/to non-Schengen is only permitted via the international airports and via aerodromes authorized
by customs and federal police. Information to be found in the AIP.

LU.answer_html: ELNT forget about it.
