SE.answer_html: Immigration must be available. Ref. airport entry in AIP.

CH.answer_html: Usually airport have PN. You can find list of airport with custom here https://www.bazg.admin.ch/bazg/en/home/information-individuals/declaring-goods/importation-into-switzerland/crossborder-flights.html

GB.answer_html: Use a designated airport listed here https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/general-aviation-operators-and-pilots-notification-of-flights/general-aviation-report-guidance-accessible

GG.answer_html: Must complete FPL, a GAR: https://www.gov.gg/Generalaviationpolicy, and get PPR (ASG, Aiglle or Aeroclub)

JE.answer_html: Jersey or Guernsey (as appropriate) Gendec to be filed for ALL arrivals (including inter island between bailiwicks) - [required in advance or on arrival?]

HU.answer_html: Hungary is in Schengen. Arrivals from non‑Schengen (or other ‘third countries’) must use an airport where border police and customs are available (LHBP, LHSM,LHDC and a few designated regional airports on PPR). A flight plan is mandatory and you must respect the published customs/immigration opening hours and lead times (PPR) in the AIP or aerodrome briefing info.

IE.answer_html:
Ireland is non Schengen.  
Per AIP GEN 1.2.1:  Aircraft landing in the territory of Ireland must first land at an International aerodrome or at a licensed aerodrome where customs and immigration facilities are available. Aircraft departing must finally depart from an International Aerodrome or from an aerodrome where customs and immigration facilities are available.
Irish GAR form here:  https://flyinginireland.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/IrishGARForm.pdf
The notice period is governed by the agreement between the airport and customs rather than being on a statutory basis.  Typcially is it 24 hours notice for flights involving EU/UK nationals and 48 hours for non EU/UK nationals with the exception of 2 hours notice being typical for flights between Ireland / Northern Ireland. Practice and legal theory are far apart.  Airfields with varying levels of authorisation for non-commercial traffic have varying timing requirements for emailing a GAR form (copy of UK one) to Customs, who rarely appear on site.  Their "National Profiling Centre" seems to keep an eye out for suspicious activity and leaves the rest of us alone.

IT.answer_html: Some airports not prepared fro non shengen operations (LICJ is one of them). Even if supported by AIP sometime takes long time to handle it. I use the rule to exit and enter Schengen outside of Italy. By the way: entering Schengen area in Italy create lot of confusion in customs ( sometime is required to proove VAT paid for aircraft etc).

MT.answer_html: Mandatory handling for non-local flights. Exemption for locally-based training flights. Handlers will take care of everything

NO.answer_html: Norway is not a EU member, but is included in the Schengen agreement. You have to check with the Norwegian authorities and notified the customs before entering .

PL.answer_html: You should arrive at airport where customs and border services operate

questions.question_id: What are the rules for joining a visual circuit?
questions.question_raw: What are the rules for joining a visual circuit?
questions.question_text: What are the rules for joining a visual circuit?

BE.answer_html: The preferred entry method is a 45-degree angle to the left downwind leg for left-hand patterns

FR.answer_html: downwind join, with overhead check of airfield if no afis. Base or straightin possible if communication/coordination with afis or tower

DE.answer_html: General procedure is to enter the published circuit mid downwind at curuit altitude with an angle of 45 degrees

LU.answer_html: ELLX has specific tracks; see VAC charts; other fields no experience (unlikely a foreigner would visit them)\

NL.answer_html: 90 degrees mid-downwind, circuit altitude

SE.answer_html: None beside SERA.

CH.answer_html: downwind join and overhead check of parameters

GG.answer_html: 700ft AGL (1,000 ft MSL) for EGJB and EGJA

JE.answer_html: no really applicable

HU.answer_html: Ah it's a tricki question. Always check the airport manual if it is available or visit this site https://ais.hungarocontrol.hu/vfrmanual The reason for this is that some airport has srict trafficpatterns due environmental and residental reason.

IE.answer_html: At aerodromes with ATS join as instructed, uncontrolled airfields join overhead. Conform to local rules, overhead join preferred where airspace allows.

MT.answer_html: Max 3 aircraft in the circuit. Make a request to the releavnt ATC controller. Per ATC clearance

NO.answer_html: Depends from airport to airport and there is no "fixed rules" as I know of.

PL.answer_html: contact terminal information service, request instructions, if ther's nobody on radio than blind broadcast your position and intentions to inform traffic

questions.question_id: What are the rules pertaining to the use of local language?
questions.question_raw: What are the rules pertaining to the use of local language?
questions.question_text: What are the rules pertaining to the use of local language?

BE.answer_html: English only

FR.answer_html: You can use local language (french) or english. Some airport will have restriction for French only indicated in the VAC plate, some will revert to French only when ATS is not active

DE.answer_html: IFR:  English mandatory  VFR: (FIS/Tower/Information/Radio)  English/German      Some small airfields are German only!

LU.answer_html: Only English is used on the radio ; in practice like ~everywhere the first transmission may start with an informal « hello », « good morning », « good afternoon », …

NL.answer_html: English only

SE.answer_html: Local language can always be used and usually is used for VFR.

CH.answer_html: You can always use english with ATC, airfield or FIS will support an additional local language as well. Ex: Geneva French, Bern German, etc

JE.answer_html: English spoken

HU.answer_html: Hungarian is widely used on the radio at small GA airfields and glider/UL sites, but in controlled airspace (Budapest ACC/APP/TWR and most CTR/TMA) the working language is English. Most regional controlled aerodromes can also accommodate Hungarian locally, but foreign traffic will always be handled in English. For international flights you should assume English only and use Hungarian only when both parties clearly speak it.

IE.answer_html: English is the operational language

IT.answer_html: Generaly speaking english is used. If ATC recognize italian pilot sometime swith to italian languiage but rarely. Italian pilots switch to italian language only for greetings. 99% english is used

MT.answer_html: English is the official RT langunage to be used in Maltese airspace and is a requiremenet. All RT in English

NO.answer_html: Local language is usually not used, but sometimes it can be used for more complicated messages and emergencies, but this is not so common.

PL.answer_html: English can be used in communication

questions.question_id: What electronic conspicuity is generally in use in your country?
questions.question_raw: What electronic conspicuity is generally in use in your country?
questions.question_text: What electronic conspicuity is generally in use in your country?

BE.answer_html: Flight Information Service, Safesky app

FR.answer_html: SDVFR, skydemon, foreflight,

DE.answer_html: TCAS, ADS-B, Flarm

LU.answer_html: transponder / ADS-B; I’m not aware that the gliders use FLARM

NL.answer_html: Mix of Mode S only and ADSB-out Transponder mandatory >1.200ft. When transponder equiped always on ALT.

SE.answer_html: ADS-B, Flarm (but I would say both are in limited use by powered GA)

HU.answer_html: In Hungary all of the radar facility is MODE S capable and there are very good coverage so primary conspicuity is Mode S SSR transponders they are very common on powered GA aircraft. ADS‑B Out via Mode S extended squitter is increasingly common on newer avionics but not yet universal. FLARM (and compatible systems/OGN) is widespread in the gliding community and the OGN is mandatory for LHBS and LHTL if you fly several traffic pattern so the flight schools install OGN in every training aircraft. Various application based systems (SafeSky etc.) are used informally but have no regulatory status. There is a hungarian application called pilot.net and GA VFR.

IE.answer_html: Regrettably there is not very much in use.  Better-equipped types will have ADSB in/out.  Pilot Aware lacks ground stations.  Mode S Transponders / ADSB.

IT.answer_html: no experience, i have it embedded in my plane (Cirrus SF50 )

MT.answer_html: Locally based aircraft are assigned a specific squawk code. TCAS and ADSB, and mandatory Mode A/C

NO.answer_html: Skydemon, Foreflight and Garmin Pilot (and I think that is the correct order in popularity).

PL.answer_html: no regulations in G/VFR, FIS gives information on traffic
